Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p:
Consulate General of the United States,
Monrovia, Liberia, Feb'y 2nd, 1880.
Mr. J. H. Smyth to the Assistant Sec'y, State.
The inability of Hon. P. S. Hamel, the appointed to serve the Government in consequence of his expectant removal shortly to another post.

Consulate General of the United States,
Monrovia, Liberia, Feb'y 2, 1880.

I have the honor to respectfully inform you that I received, Jan'y 31, 1880, a dispatch from the recently appointed Consular Agent, Hon. P. S. Hamel Consul Gen'l of the Netherlands of W. C. of Africa, dated Jan'y 20, 1880, in which he declines to accept the office of U.S. Consular Agent, at Cape Coast Castle.

Mr. H., says, "I am unable to accept the appointment, as in all probability
Hon. John Hay,
Ass't Secretary, State,
Washington D.C.
probability my Government will at an early date do away with the office of Consul General for the West Coast of Africa and only leave a Consular Agent at Elmina, so that I expect to be recalled soon.
Mr. H., is to be sent to Rio de Janeiro being about to be promoted.

With considerations of esteem
I am, Sir,
Your obd't serv't,
Jno. H. Smyth
U.S. Consul Gen'l
